body:
I don't think it is the correct decision to disable scalar replacement for embedded mode only just because of printing stack trace to stderr. 

Also, I think making more differences in work between embedded and distributed mode is not a good idea. 

If we want to disable scalar replacement, we should do that independently of running mode or used client.
@vdiravka please review.

@paul-rogers thanks for the great review. I tried to solve all the issues described above. If I missed something, please let me know. Also, can you take a look at new changes?

@priteshm I will try to make changes in time.
Fair point @vvysotskyi . @chunhui-shi Would you have time to disable scalar replacement for all modes?
@arina-ielchiieva @kkhatua would this make it into the 1.14 release?
@bitblender would you be able to address the remaining review comments in time for the batch commit this week?

Yes.

@ppadma @Ben-Zvi Do you guys have time to look at this PR? If not, I can help review pieces of it to help speed things up.

@bitblender Looks like this is pretty close to being done and has already been +1'ed. Could you just fix conflicts and push your latest changes addressing the review comments, and indicate which comments you addressed and which comments you decided to leave as is. After that I'll add the **ready-to-commit** tag.
@ilooner yes Tim. that will certainly be helpful. thx a lot.
@ilooner thanks for helping out here. Please do prioritize this review.
@arina-ielchiieva I've done some additional changes, please review.

One issue not covered is memory used by non-buffered operators. This change seems to advocate use of " max_query_memory_per_node == DirectMemory ", which can easily lead to an OOM -- All the buffered instances get a (promised) share of the MQMPN, but at runtime some memory is taken by other operators (e.g., scanners), so if **all** the buffered operator instances would try to use **almost all** of their promised memory, the JVM would OOM.

Maybe I'd open another Jira for that; introducing another new option to **reserve** a percentage of the direct memory, hence forcing the MQMPN to be lower than the DirectMemory.
@sohami  Addressed all your review comments. Please take a look again.

@Ben-Zvi / @parthchandra  - I have written a description in the JIRA to give idea about current implementation of Sort, motivation behind current approach for supporting EMIT outcome and what future enhancements can be done. Please let me know if it looks good.
@ilooner I have addressed all the comments and I am running the changes through the pre-commit framework. You can go ahead and mark it as ready-to-commit
@ilooner @Ben-Zvi let me know when you are done looking at my latest round of changes in response to the review comments. I will rebase on master, fix the conflict and force push.

@sachouche I still need to read things more in depth, so I will continue to add comments as I get a better understanding of the code.

At a high level, I didn't see any unit tests added for the new classes and code. Since this is a significant new feature, we need to add tests. Let's try to come up with a plan for what we can add unit tests for and how. Perhaps we could start with BatchSizingMemoryUtil.java and work from there.
Thanks @bitblender +1 LGTM
+1, LGTM.
@vdiravka thanks for making the changes. +1 LGTM.

This causes unit test failures:
`Results :

Tests in error: 
  TestHashAggrSpill.testNoPredictHashAggrSpill » UserRemote SYSTEM ERROR: IndexO...
  TestHashAggrSpill.testHashAggrSecondaryTertiarySpill » UserRemote SYSTEM ERROR...
  TestHashAggrSpill.testSimpleHashAggrSpill » UserRemote SYSTEM ERROR: IndexOutO...

Tests run: 3211, Failures: 0, Errors: 3, Skipped: 156`


https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DRILL-6479?focusedCommentId=16520713&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-16520713

@Ben-Zvi @ilooner I addressed all code review comments. I got rid of the while loops. Instead, I am adjusting the idx based on batch size when a new batch gets added.  This should address the performance concerns while keeping heterogenous batch sizes. Also, I am adjusting the output row count if incoming batch memory sizing changes. 
Please take a look and give me feedback.
@sohami done 2 of the 3 changes (comment updates). Please review
The bug was found; the fix is in the second commit. I will squash the second commit after testing and approving.
LGTM from code changes. But please make sure all the pre-commit tests are passing.
@h4ck3rm1k3 the issue of DRILL-386 is unrelated. Can you put the correct JIRA number for contextual reference?

I did not understand why  50% of output batches will exceed the configured output batch size. 
Let me setup a meeting to discuss.
Added a new test to test the Batch Sizing Memory utility and fixed formatting.
I am going to start over from scratch on this.
@parthchandra, can you review this?
Done
@vvysotskyi please review.

Also, after the changes made in DRILL-6438, method `BaseTestQuery.printResult()` do nothing, but it should print the result to stdout.
Could you please fix it?
@vdiravka please review.
@vdiravka please review.
@KazydubB  Do you know why the PR isn't added to Jira automatically? Please add the link there.
@vdiravka, added the link to Jira.
@ilooner @Ben-Zvi I removed the code that dynamically updates the row count. Please review.

Thanks @ppadma ! These change eliminate quite a bit of useless computation. Is there any need/plan to allow concurrent access to the RecordBatchSizer in the future? With these changes, access to the RecordBatchSizer will have more synchronization points for concurrent access. Earlier, ouputRowCount was the only field that was mutated after creating a RecordBatch object. Now many more fields are being changed.  I just wanted to raise that one point. Otherwise, LGTM +1
@bitblender thanks Karthik. RecordBatchSizer is being created by each operator when they get a new batch. I don't see any need for concurrent access, atleast in the near future.

I disagree with you. A method is called `printResult` but not `logResult` etc.

Regarding log fixture, this method is in `BaseTestQuery`, so I don't think that mixing two testing approaches even for debugging is a good idea.

I don't propose to change the behavior for `VectorUtil.showVectorAccessibleContent()`, may be added a separate method which prints the result to stdout and common logic with `VectorUtil.showVectorAccessibleContent()` may be moved to the separate method.
@vdiravka, thanks for the code review. Comments are addressed.

Value for `NUM_PROJECT_COLUMNS` was increased from 2000 to 5000 in DRILL-5140 to check that generated class is splitted to several classes to avoid CompileException when class constant pool has too many items. 

In the case without the fix, these tests failed for `NUM_PROJECT_COLUMNS=5000`. But for 2500 they still passed. So I think, we should leave this value as it is and increase the timeout, or move these tests to drill-test-framework.

@vvysotskyi Thanks for catching this. Would decreasing the number of columns for just testEXTERNAL_SORT and testTOP_N_SORT to 2500, but keeping a column count of 5000 for all the other tests be sufficient to test that corner case?

@vvysotskyi The LogFixture is just a utility to adjust log levels, it could be used anywhere and doesn't include any test framework specific code. Also the goal is to remove all usages of **System.out** from the code base as discussed previously https://github.com/apache/drill/pull/1284 , http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/drill-dev/201805.mbox/browser and rely completely on the logging framework for output . In order to do that we have to use loggers everywhere we need to output information. I propose to do the following to address your concerns:

1. **VectorUtil.showVectorAccessibleContent()** continues using a logger.
2. **BaseTestQuery.printResult** includes the `try(LogFixture logFixture = new LogFixture.LogFixtureBuilder()...)`boilerplate to output to stdout by default.
3. We add a new method **BaseTestQuery.logResult** which does not turn on output to stdout by default.
4. We replace all usages of **BaseTestQuery.printResult** with **BaseTestQuery.logResult** in the tests.
Thanks for the proposal, all these points look good.
@sachouche @sohami please review.

@vvysotskyi @ilooner  NUM_PROJECT_COLUMNS controls 3 other tests besides testTopN and testExternalSort - testPARQUET_WRITER(), testTEXT_Writer and TestProject.  How about we set NUM_PROJECT_COLUMNS=2500 and then introduce a new constant NUM_PROJECT_TEST_COLUMNS=10000 for testProject? Basically, reduce the stress on SORTers and WRITERs but bump up the column count on testProject to a number which will push the code generated for Project over the constant pool limit. testProject takes about 130s on my Mac with 10000 columns.
@sohami Please review

Me might consider the following as well:
1. Rename VectorUtil.showVectorAccessibleContent() -> VectorUtil.logVectorAccessibleContent() 
2. Document usage of LogFixture in dev docs to output the results to stdout.
@Ben-Zvi addressed review comments. please take a look.

Thx @vvysotskyi @arina-ielchiieva. I will do the rename of showVectorAccessibleContent and add to the devdocs as well. Also @bitblender just showed me another issue, where he expected the QueryBuilder.printXXX methods to display output as well. So we would have to make a similar adjustment to those methods as well.
@ilooner maybe we can consider allowing stout to ease debugging but fail during project build if left in unit tests?
@vvysotskyi Thanks for making the code changes. Code changes look good to me. +1.
ping @amansinha100 @parthchandra or someone else would be pleased to review this PR.

I am not convinced that a user should be able to change the amount of logging from a client session. A user may cause an excessive logging and bring Drill cluster down. In addition, an end user may not have access to drillbit logs, so changing log level is useless. Ability to change log levels must be granted only to an admin who has access to logback.xml and logs.

@vrozov 
The logging functionality is not exposed to end users. All batch stats flags are internal.

- Updated code based on most recent comments
- Fixed a compilation failure due to changes in the Batch Sizer APIs made in recently committed PRs
@weijietong thanks for the PR.  Yes, this is high on my list to review.  I am tied up until tomorrow but will review during the weekend.

@Ben-Zvi - Can you please review this ?

Issue was in BuildSchema phase TopN was receiving NONE outcome from upstream and there was a missing return statement in switch block which leads to NONE handling as EMIT handling and hence the exception.
@Agirish we might consider adding button to export all enabled plugins in one json file as well, rather then doing one by one. What do you think?
@vdiravka one more thought, we can add button on Web UI which will export all available plugins in hocon format. @Agirish is doing similar work on exporting storage plugins to json in PR #1350.

@vrozov I discussed the logging with @sachouche. The issue is that some information needed to be logged for QA purposes on a per query basis, and for ease of testing needed to be toggled from the sqlline. This was the agreed on approach by the batch sizing team, so at this point we're coming in at the end of a series of discussions. Nevertheless I spent about half a day to find a way this use case could be met in a logback centric way, and I could not find a reasonable alternative that could be done without a large amount of work.

The main issue is that slf4j / logback has global logging configurations, which makes it impossible to turn on logging on a per query bases. We can use MDC to include a query id in the log messages and we could filter by query, but even that is not ideal since you are generating logs you don't need for all queries. Then there is the issue of updating the logging configuration. The only logback native method is to enable periodic scanning of the logback.xml file and to update the logback.xml file on all nodes when you want to enable certain logging. That is not a great experience for someone automating tests, or debugging.

The conclusion we came to was that Drill needs a real logging solution, and to really do it right you would have to go down the rabbit hole.

  1. Enable per query logging configurations, not just a global logging configuration. To do this we would have to use thread local loggers instead of static loggers, or something like https://clogr.io/, or a custom ContextSelector https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38208617/practical-use-of-logback-context-selectors.
  2. Allow either sql line configuration of log levels or web ui configuration of log levels (like Apex had).
  3. Include a logging context with the query context to communicate the logging config for a query.

These are non trivial, have a lot of corner cases, and require design discussions with the community.

For the interim Salim is making the options controlling logging internal, so users will not see them. Then he is going to have a follow up PR to consolidate the logging across all the batch sizing operators. Later when we have a real logging solution we can delete these options and do the right thing.

@arina-ielchiieva, I thought about that - but it's a bit more complicated in how i'd like it to be: An "Export All" button" should export each of the storage plugin configurations into JSON files and generate a single compressed folder which contains each of these JSON files individually. 
And an "Import" button which can support importing either a single JSON file or a compressed folder which can create one or more storage plugins. 

I think having individual export button is helpful. We could keep it in the "Update" page (image 2 above). We could remove it from the main storage plugin list page (image 1) if you think it's cluttering the UI. 

In a later PR, we can add support for the "Export All" and "Import" (one or more) buttons. Would that be okay?

Sounds fair regarding the enhancement Jira. I think keeping export button even in update mode is also good. Please create Jira for the enhancement for import / export all. Also why you think import all should export each plugin in different file, it can export all in one (similar as we have for bootstrap plugins)?
WIP: going to exclude unneeded dependencies from dependencies added to dependencyManagement.

Filed DRILL-6562 to track this. 

Regarding one vs multiple files, my reasoning was to keep it more human readable and flexible - giving options to selectively import any plugin as needed. So suggested a compressed folder with each of the plugin files. But your approach sounds good. I'm thinking the "Export All" option would be used for All or None scenarios. And the regular per plugin "Export" option being introduced in this PR can support the flexible per plugin import.

If logging needs to be enabled just for QA purposes, I still don't see why it needs to be enabled per query or be dynamic and can't be managed by logging.xml. Additionally, if I understand "QA purpose", batch sizes needs to be validated by unit testing, not by looking at the logs.

@vrozov My understanding was the following. QA has setup automatic tests of both the performance of batch sizing as well as correctness on a real cluster. Each batch sizing change has unit tests to validate batch size. But on a real cluster with real data, the only viable way to validate right now for QA is to check the batch sizes output by an operator is through logging. Since Drill takes testing on real clusters seriously and aims to do more than just unit tests, I think this is perfectly acceptable.

Since logging has overhead, and QA wanted to automate both the performance and correctness tests, they required the ability to turn logging off via sql line. This was the approach agreed on by developers and testers in the Drill community including @sachouche, @bitblender, @ppadma, robert (don't know his github id), and @priteshm.

Given the scope of agreement in the community, the fact that similar changes have already been merged, and also to minor impact on the drill code itself ~20 lines; I suggest moving this discussion to a separate change. In my investigation I was not able to find a viable alternative to this approach, @vrozov perhaps you could present an alternative approach on the dev list and lead the proposal. It would be a great help moving forward.

In the meantime the changes proposed here represent a valuable performance improvement for the Drill community, so let's not hold up this change over this.
I'll work on adding the instructions into both the docs dir on this repo and the write-up on Parth's repo once the PR is in.
@akumarb2010 is this ready to be committed?
I do see that a similar approach is followed for other operators for batch sizing. I do agree with @ilooner that it would be good to discuss alternative proposals on a separate JIRA.
@Ben-Zvi Thank you Boaz for the thorough review and giving me a +1 finally.
@ilooner can you also take a look at it?
I'd be more comfortable with single plugins to avoid any possible corruption (e.g. format, etc) as debugging could be a nightmare.

@arina-ielchiieva , on second thoughts, i think having a separate profile is better. Created a new profile called 'docker'. Let me know if it looks good. 
Steps remain mostly similar:
Build Project (any profile can be provided. If it's 'docker' profile, then docker image is built)
`$ mvn clean install`
Build Docker image Push image to Docker Hub (or any Container Registry):
```
cd distribution
mvn dockerfile:build -Pdocker
mvn dockerfile:push -Pdocker
```

@priteshm will take a look monday.
@vrozov please fix conflict and travis failures.
@ilooner I'll rebase after review. Travis CI failure is not related to the change, it failed due to the build exceeding Travis CI limit.

@kkhatua, can you please review this fix?

Thanks!

@bitblender, can you please review this PR?

Thanks!
@amansinha100  Thank you for the review.

@sachouche  The change looks simple, but I might be missing the bigger picture. For e.g., `ColumnPrecisionInfo.precision` is passed as an unused argument. Not clear as to why you would not need it still.
Perhaps someone else who is more familiar could review this.
@Agirish I think having separate docker profile is good idea.
+1, thanks for making the changes.
Thanks all, for the review!

The reason I didn't remove the ColumnPrecisionInfo.precision is that I am allowing myself another chance, in the future, to optimize the fixed length path; at this time, the savings are very less (about 2kb). Though, I can remove this input object if it helps code clarity.
@ppadma, could you please resolve merge conflicts?

@vvysotskyi Done.
I accidentally closed the PR. Reopened it.
Unit tests in travis build for this PR failed, @ppadma, could you please take a look at this?
@akumarb2010 - Thank you for reviewing the design and implementation, and providing valuable inputs.
@vvysotskyi sorry about that. fixed the problem.updated the PR.
@amansinha100  The scan node's memory copy logic has removed. Thanks for the knowledge of `SelectionVectorPrelVisitor.addSelectionRemoverWhereNecessary`. I appreciate what you payed out. Thanks!
@vvysotskyi please review.
